results.title: You'd have to be mad to like opera
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian Opera”.
Explores the personality of opera singer Isobel Buchanan, and gives an insight into her life as an opera singer. She is seen in a number of situations which show the wide range of activities and disciplines which go towards the making of an opera. Particular emphasis is placed on rehearsal and actual performance of the opera ‘Don Pasquale’. Production manager, Roy Bissell; director, script, Karl McPhee; editor, Ian Walker; sound, Rodney Simmons; photographer, Andrew Fraser.

results.title: Man feeding his dogs: oil by Russell Drysdale
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
A small but powerful painting by Russell Drysdale, which combines starkness with lyricism. The artist talks about his reactions to the picture and his problems in painting it, and his style and technique of underpainting and glazing.

results.brief_description: These films are designed for use by art teachers in secondary schools, by art galleries and the art-loving public generally. Each film examines in close detail one master work.

results.title: 'Mount William from Mount Dryden'...by Eugene Guerard, 1857
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Eugene Von Guerard, (affectionately known as ‘the father of the Gallery School’ Victoria, being founder), with his training in the naturalistic German school of Romanticism, was able to produce works that express reverence for nature’s mysterious processes as well as appreciation of the splendours of the untamed Australian landscape. The European concept of sublimity is discussed and some of Von Guerard’s most majestic works are studied.

results.title: Epiphany
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Ian Fairweather’s ‘Epiphany’ (1962) which describes events to come in the life of the child Jesus, is considered by many of his admirers to be his greatest work. The film examines this powerful, sombre painting in detail, illuminating its intricacies and drawing on other related works by the artist, including a number of rarely seen canvasses from private collections

results.title: The Mother
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Life and paintings of George W. Lambert, flamboyant Australian war artist, painter and poet, including the important painting “The Mother”. Talks of how he encouraged young painters including Roland Wakelin and Grace Cossington Smith and his involvement as a war artist and memorial sculptor. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Facts for girls
results.creator_credit: Alfred Kelman, Robert E. Fuisz and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Body Human”.
Illustrations of the female biological functions are interspersed with informal, live-action discussions at an all-girls’ slumber party, on a jogging track and during other typical teenage activities. Besides the female anatomy, they discuss menstruation, reproduction and the girls’ hopes and fears. Narrated by Marlo Thomas and photographed by Don Lenzer.

results.title: The Blue planet
results.creator_credit: Alastair Fothergill, Discovery Channel and BBC
results.brief_description: A definitive study of the Earth’s sea exploring the extraordinary life of the creatures that inhabit its depths, and the behaviour of the water as it is influenced by the changing currents and tides. Narrated by David Attenborough. For more information go to http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/programmes/tv/blueplanet/
